MARKET RECAP

The energy sector outperformed following the rally in crude. Lululemon (LULU) opened higher after reporting a beat on top and bottom line estimates. T-Mobile US (TMUS) was under pressure on the news that the telecoms co.’s proposed merger with Sprint (S) could face additions delays and legal hurdles. Disney (DIS) caught a bid after Morgan Stanley raised its price target for the co. on optimism for its streaming service. Twitter (TWTR) sunk after Moffett Nathanson cut its profit target for the social media platform to the second lowest on the Street. Tyson Foods (TSN) opened higher after overnight reports that the food maker was poised to enter the plant-based meat market, rivalling incumbents such as Beyond Meat (BYND), who sunk on the news. Colgate-Palmolive (CL) was under pressure after executives said that “there has been a little bit of softness in the US market”. Lockheed Martin (LMT) opened solidly in the green, after it said that it was a year ahead of its goal of cutting the cost of the F-35 to USD 80mln per jet. Target (TGT) opened higher, after the co. announced in a blog post that its same-day delivery is now available through its website, but eventually gave away most of these gains. Lennar Corp (LEN) was buoyed after receiving an upgrade to outperform at Wedbush. Uber (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) moved higher after Evercore initiated both with an 'outperform'. S&P 500 0.4% at 2892, NASDAQ-100 0.5% at 7511, Dow Jones 0.4% at 26107.

The Treasury curve bull-steepened after geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, while traders also cited increasing expectations of Fed rate cuts also pushing shorter-dated yields lower. 2-year yields came in by over 6bps, while longer-dated yields were around 2.5bps lower. The US Treasury auctioned 30-year debt, stopping through the screens by 0.4bps, while cover rose vs recent averages and the prior auction; the foreign bid remained (as was seen in all auctions this week), with indirect participation remaining above the previous auction as well as recent averages. Friday’s retail sales data is the final piece of the data puzzle ahead of next week’s FOMC meeting; markets are pricing a 28% chance of a rate cut at the June meeting (which comes ahead of the G20 on 28-29th June, which will set the tone for trade wars, and global growth expectations); accordingly there is more aggressive pricing for a July rate cut, which is now over 100% implied, according to money markets, suggesting that the market is increasingly pricing in the possibility of a 50bps rate cut, instead of the ‘usual’ 25bps. At settlement, major curve spreads were wider, with 2s30s steepening by 3.5bps. US T-note futures (M9) 11+ ticks higher at 127-00.

RANsquawk US Market Wrap - 13th June 2019: US blames Iran for attacks on Gulf of Oman
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

US MARKET WRAP - 13 JUNE 2019: US blames Iran for attacks on Gulf of Oman

 

* SNAPSHOT: Equites up, Treasuries up, Dollar flat, Crude up.

* REAR VIEW: US Sec of State Pompeo says Iran to blame for Gulf of Oman attacks; Trump says Iran not ready to make deal; UK’s Johnson gains large support in first leadership ballot.

* COMING UP: China industrial output, retail sales; French and Italian final CPI; US Retail Sales, Industrial Production, Uni of Mich, Baker Hughes; ECB’s Lautenschlager; BoE’s Carney; G20 Energy Ministers.

 

* GULF OF OMAN: US Secretary of State Pompeo said Iran was to blame for the attacks on two tankers in the Gulf of Oman, adding that Iran was continuing to actively work to interrupt flows of oil. US President Trump feels that it is too soon to even think about making a deal with Iran, adding that both sides were not yet ready. A White House official said that the US is discussing options with allies on the protection of international shipping to the Gulf; adding that the US wants to ensure freedom of navigation, and that international commerce is not disrupted, believing that more attacks could follow. As the case for ratcheting up pressure on Iran is being made, it is worth highlighting that on Wednesday Iran said it would not attack anyone, but if it was attacked, it would defend itself. The incident came around a month after previous attacks in the region, with countries including the US and Saudi claiming Iran was behind those too.

* CHINA: A White House spokesperson, when asked if US President Trump will meet Chinese President Xi at the G20 Summit, said "it looks like we're moving that way". NEC Director Kudlow later echoed this by saying that the US intends to have a Trump-Xi meeting at the G20, but it had not yet been formalised.

* RUSSIA: Following Trump’s suggestion that he was mulling sanctions on the Nord Stream 2, Russian President Putin said that tensions with the US were worsening. This comes alongside Trump announcing that the US and Poland would be sending troops to Poland, in a deterrence measure against Russia. A Russian Lawmaker also said that US plans to deploy spy drones in Poland is of concern to Moscow, stating that Poland could be targeted in a retaliatory strike in the scenario of an attack on Russia.

* BREXIT: The first ballot vote on PM May’s successor saw Boris Johnson finish well ahead of the pack, securing 114 votes, where Jeremy Hunt came second with 43; Andrea Leadsom, Mark Haper, and Esther McVay were eliminated leaving seven candidates to take part in the second vote on Tuesday, 18th June. The pound saw brief downside as Johnson garnered more support than anticipate, and as such, keeps the threat of a no-deal Brexit alive.

* ITALY: When asked if Italy will finance planned tax cuts through deficit, Italian Deputy PM Di Maio said Italy "will do what Italians need". EU finance ministers took a firm line: EU’s Moscovici commented that he needs new data and a clear path from Italy that shows it complies with fiscal rules in 2019 and 2020 if they are to avert disciplinary procedures. Also, EU’s Dombrovskis said that Italy needs to adopt substantial fiscal corrections to meet EU targets.

* ECB: ECB's Villeroy (Dovish) said that monetary policy must be kept accommodative as long as the Eurozone is not at its inflation target, adding that the ECB can do more if the current downturn worsens.

* SNB REVIEW: As expected, the SNB left rates unchanged at -0.75%. The Bank did not change policy towards or the language surrounding FX, reiterating that the situation in FX market is still fragile, maintaining that expansionary monetary policy and intervention are essential. However, it noted that the CHF is stronger than it was in March; notably, this is not a change in the language surrounding FX as some had been expecting the assessment around the CHF’s value to be upgraded to ‘significantly overvalued’.

* WTI (N9) SETTLES USD 1.14 HIGHER AT 52.28/BBL; BRENT (Q9) SETTLES USD 1.34 HIGHER AT USD 61.31/BBL: Energy markets have spiked on Thursday with thanks to the escalation of geopolitical tensions, however, some of the move pared back throughout the day. Prices surged on the announcement of the tanker attacks. The most immediate threat to the global supply chain would be the halting of shipping through the Strait of Hormuz, which sees approximately 40% of annual seaborne crude flow and is effectively controlled by Iran; if it were to shut, this could lead to military escalation amongst Iran and other local nations putting a lot more crude supply at risk. Later, Saudi Energy Minister Al Falih said KSA is committed to providing guaranteed oil supplies to international markets, and added that energy giant Saudi Aramco has increased readiness to deal with attacks.

* OPEC REPORT: OPEC released its monthly report, and in fitting with the recent narrative of slowing global growth, cut its 2019 global oil demand forecast to 1.14mln BPD, down 70,000 BPD from previously. On the supply side, it was reported that production fell 236k BPD in May to 29.88mln BPD. Comparing this to the EIA STEO on Tuesday, OPEC’s oil demand downgrade is smaller than the EIA’s 160k BPD cut, however the EIA sees higher total global demand growth at 1.22mln BPD. IEA is next to report on Friday.

* US T-NOTE FUTURES (M9) 11+ TICKS HIGHER AT 127-00: The Treasury curve bull-steepened after geopolitical tensions in the Middle East, while traders also cited increasing expectations of Fed rate cuts also pushing shorter-dated yields lower. 2-year yields came in by over 6bps, while longer-dated yields were around 2.5bps lower. The US Treasury auctioned 30-year debt, stopping through the screens by 0.4bps, while cover rose vs recent averages and the prior auction; the foreign bid remained (as was seen in all auctions this week), with indirect participation remaining above the previous auction as well as recent averages. Friday’s retail sales data is the final piece of the data puzzle ahead of next week’s FOMC meeting; markets are pricing a 28% chance of a rate cut at the June meeting (which comes ahead of the G20 on 28-29th June, which will set the tone for trade wars, and global growth expectations); accordingly there is more aggressive pricing for a July rate cut, which is now over 100% implied, according to money markets, suggesting that the market is increasingly pricing in the possibility of a 50bps rate cut, instead of the ‘usual’ 25bps. At settlement, major curve spreads were wider, with 2s30s steepening by 3.5bps.

* S&P 500 0.4% at 2892, NASDAQ-100 0.5% at 7511, Dow Jones  0.4% at 26107; SECTORS: Consumer Discretionary  0.9%, Consumer Staples  0.1%, Energy  1.3%, Financials  0.2%, Health Care  -0.1%, Industrials  0.5%, Information Technology  0.2%, Materials  0.6%, Telecommunication Services  1.1%, Utilities  0.2%

* STOCK SPECIFICS: The energy sector outperformed following the rally in crude. Lululemon (LULU) opened higher after reporting a beat on top and bottom line estimates. T-Mobile US (TMUS) was under pressure on the news that the telecoms co.’s proposed merger with Sprint (S) could face additions delays and legal hurdles. Disney (DIS) caught a bid after Morgan Stanley raised its price target for the co. on optimism for its streaming service. Twitter (TWTR) sunk after Moffett Nathanson cut its profit target for the social media platform to the second lowest on the Street. Tyson Foods (TSN) opened higher after overnight reports that the food maker was poised to enter the plant-based meat market, rivalling incumbents such as Beyond Meat (BYND), who sunk on the news. Colgate-Palmolive (CL) was under pressure after executives said that “there has been a little bit of softness in the US market”. Lockheed Martin (LMT) opened solidly in the green, after it said that it was a year ahead of its goal of cutting the cost of the F-35 to USD 80mln per jet. Target (TGT) opened higher, after the co. announced in a blog post that its same-day delivery is now available through its website, but eventually gave away most of these gains. Lennar Corp (LEN) was buoyed after receiving an upgrade to outperform at Wedbush. Uber (UBER) and Lyft (LYFT) moved higher after Evercore initiated both with an 'outperform'.

* FX WRAP: Havens are bid amid geopolitical tensions in the Middle East. However, JPY remains in the middle of its 108.00-108.50 range, XAU is towards the top end of its recent c.1325-1350 range, while the CHF is also higher, given support from the SNB rate decision. The DXY has been meandering, but is around neutral heading into the APAC session; in early trade, the USD was dictating the tone, and even small moves were reverberating more widely in other FX. GBP has not reclaimed 1.27, and saw brief downside after Brexiteer and frontrunner Boris Johnson emerged with larger than expected support from the first leadership ballot; 1.2670 has been decent support on Thursday. CAD is higher, tracking oil prices, although NOK could not muster gains against the EUR nor the USD. AUD is lower after the jobs report; analysts said that, despite a better headline, the data still bolsters the case for RBA rate cuts, although the timing is uncertain. TRY is bucking the EMFX trend, after higher oil prices, tensions over the S-400 missile system and weak data put pressure on the Lira. RUB also trades lower, with Trump’s mulling of sanctions on Nord Stream 2 pipeline getting wider airing. BRL is firmed after optimism over pension reform, where policymakers see savings above what has been recently expected.

subject: Daily FX Wrap: Dollar extends post-US CPI comeback, as Lira retreats further from post-CBRT peaks
content:
USD

The DXY has now eclipsed 97.000 as the Greenback continues to rebound from recent lows, with the index probing above bullish technical levels at 97.020 and 97.033 (100 and 200 DMAs respectively) on its way to 97.086. The rationale, heightened US-global trade tensions and geopolitical factors prompting a broad downturn in risk sentiment to the benefit of the Buck and other safe-havens like Bullion, the Franc and Yen to varying degrees.

CHF

As noted, the Franc is among the outperformers and most sought after currencies, as Usd/Chf trades mostly below 0.9950 and Eur/Chf hovers around 1.1200, largely shrugging off latest SNB policy guidance that it is ‘essential’ to keep benchmark rates at -0.75% and actively intervene. Moreover, the Swiss Central Bank stressed that there is room to cut further and use other expansionary measures given the still high valuation assigned to the Franc, which is stronger than it was at the last quarterly review, especially as risks of further appreciation are deemed to be strong. However, the SNB also flagged unchanged benchmark rates for the entire forecast period (3 years) via its updated economic forecasts and announced that the 3 month Libor will be switched to a new reference rate based on SARON, but this does not constitute any change in policy stance.

CAD/AUD/NZD

Contrasting fortunes for the non-US Dollars, as the Loonie was cushioned from the worst risk-off flows by a spike in crude price caused by latest tanker ‘incidents’ in the Gulf of Oman, and despite China accusing Canada for the diplomatic situation over Huawei. Conversely, the Aussie and Kiwi were both hit by aversion and the former inched closer to 0.6900 in wake of overnight data revealing an unexpected uptick in the jobless rate and disproportionate rise in full vs part time workforce breakdown, underpinning RBA easing expectations. Nzd/Usd is hovering just above the base of a 0.6587-57 range as Aud/Nzd meanders midway between 1.0543-07 and attention turns to NZ manufacturing PMI.

GBP/EUR/JPY 

All choppy against the Usd as Sterling and the single currency both lost sight of big figures at 1.1300 and 1.2700 respectively for similar and separate reasons. Cable slipped through chart support at 1.2687 (10 and 21 DMA convergence) to a fresh multi-week low as new broke of the 1st Conservative Party run-off vote to find a new leader and it emerged that BoJo won by a bigger margin than expected, with 3 candidates falling out of the race. The Euro retreated further from recent peaks and under downside technical levels at 1.1280 and 1.1273 (near term support and 100 DMA), but the Yen held up better within 108.53-17 on the aforementioned safe-haven grounds.

EM 

Usd/Try extended to just shy of 5.9000 at one stage as the Lira weakened on Russian S-400, oil and Turkish reserve developments on top of Dollar strength, while Usd/Zar rallied to 14.9300 before waning as the legal probe into SA President Ramaphosa continued to weigh on sentiment alongside dovish SARB rhetoric. However, Usd/Brl fell to 3.8350 amidst bullish talk on Brazil’s pension reform bill.

subject: Tesla (TSLA) - USTR office has denied the electric automakers request for tariff exemptions on imports from its supplier SAS Automotive, who makes its Model 3 car computer
US House Speaker Pelosi says she believes Trump is involved in a criminal cover-up
White House spokesman, when asked if US President Trump will meet Chinese President Xi at the G20 Summit, says "it looks like we're moving that way"
Talking Crude: Renewed risk premium after attacks in the Persian Gulf
content:
• Supply concerns in the Strait of Hormuz are spiking energy markets on Thursday. Two tankers, one Norwegian and one Japanese, have been fired upon by torpedo missiles in the Gulf of Oman; promptly sending prices higher and paring back Wednesday’s losses. Similar to previous attacks in the region, eyes are pointing to Iran, although they have swiftly denied involvement. Worth highlighting that on Wednesday Iran said it would not attack anyone, but if it was attacked, it would defend itself. With details thin and shaky currently, if more unravel that lead to further escalation, crude markets could be set for further bounces, and wider risk assets could come under pressure.
  • Meanwhile, OPEC released its monthly report, and in fitting with the recent narrative of slowing global growth, cut its 2019 global oil demand forecast to 1.14mln BPD, down 70,000 BPD from previously. On the supply side, it was reported that production fell 236k BPD in May to 29.88mln BPD. Comparing this to the EIA STEO on Tuesday, OPEC’s oil demand downgrade is smaller than the EIA’s 160k BPD cut, however the EIA sees higher total global demand growth at 1.22mln BPD. IEA is next to report on Friday.
  • Aside from the Middle East, geopolitical tensions are rising between the US and Russia. US President Trump announced on Tuesday he is considering sanctions on Nord Steam 2, the Russian natural gas pipeline project connecting Russia to Germany, warning Germany about being dependent on Russia for fuel. Trump said, “We’re protecting Germany from Russia and Russia is getting billions and billions of dollars from Germany.” The Nord Stream 2 project makes economic sense for Europe, seeing as it needs a steady gas supply, and shipments of LNG from US companies simply cost more; but the risk, as President Trump eagerly alludes to, is that if something “bad” were to happen involving Russia it could bring Europe’s energy supply down with it. Russian President Putin has said in response on Wednesday that tensions with the US are worsening. This comes alongside Trump announcing that the US and Poland would be sending troops to Poland, in a deterrence measure against Russia.

Of note for energy names, including ExxonMobil (XOM), Chevron (CVX) and ConocoPhillips (COP): crude prices are spiking higher after two tankers have been struck off the coast of UAE, casting concerns over supply out of key shipping ways in the region.

The Republican chairman of the Senate's antitrust panel has criticized DoJ/FTC plans to potentially investigate four of the US’s largest tech firms, Alphabet (GOOGL), Apple (AAPL), Amazon (AMZN) and Facebook (FB).

DOW

  • Disney (DIS) (Communication Services/Movies & Entertainment) has had its price target raised to USD 160 from USD 135 at Morgan Stanley, where analyst Benjamin Swinburne raised his subscriber growth forecasts for its upcoming streaming service, Disney+, maintaining his Overweight rating.
  • Goldman Sachs (GS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) – The NYT reported that, allegedly, Goldman offered to pay all the fees for customers bringing legal claims against Marcus (its new consumer bank) including, in some instances, the doubling of lawyer's fees as long as the customers kept their complaints out of the public eye.
  • IBM (IBM) (Information Technology/IT Consulting & Other Services), Merck & Co (MRK) (Health Care/Pharmaceuticals), Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) and KPMG are to collaborate as part of an FDA program in support of the U.S. Drug Supply Chain Security Act, which aims to evaluate the use of blockchain to protect pharmaceutical product integrity. The program will assist drug supply chain stakeholders in developing a system for identifying and tracing certain prescription drugs distributed in US. The blockchain is likely to be integrated with existing supply chain and traceability systems, with a pilot project pencilled in for completion in Q4 2019.
  • Walmart (WMT) (Consumer Staples/Hypermarkets & Super Centres) CEO Lore announced that the department store chain is to integrate its Jet.com staff into its e-commerce operations, after the online start-up - which it acquired for USD 3.3bln in 2016 - failed to live up to expectations.

NASDAQ 100

  • Alphabet (GOOG, GOOGL) (Communication Services/Interactive Media & Services) is to remove a controversial clause in its employee manual which used to prohibit former workers from “poaching” their former colleagues at the tech giant once they have left to find a new job, according to the Silicon Valley Business Journal. Separately, the publication, Made by Google, tweeted a photo which confirmed the new Pixel 4 phone, and in further separate news, CEO Pichai sent an email to LGBTQ employees saying YouTube is taking a "hard look" at its harassment policies, reported Business Insider.
  • Amazon (AMZN) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is reportedly increasing its hiring in China across several different regions, according to Yahoo Finance. Reportedly, job postings for roles in Amazon posted in China have increased by 475% from the January 2018 low.
  • Lululemon Athletica Inc (LULU) (Consumer Discretionary /Textiles, Apparel & Luxury Goods) reports Q1 19 EPS 0.74 (exp. 0.71), revenue 0.782bln (exp. 0.76bln), SSS in low double digits. Revises FY19 EPS view lower to 4.51-4.58 (exp. 4.64), and FY19 Revenue view lower 3.73bln-3.77bln (exp. 3.77bln).
  • T-Mobile US (TMUS) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) and Sprint (S) (Communication Services/Wireless Telecommunication Services) are facing another hurdle to their proposed merger, after reports emerged alleging that a judge is likely to approve a temporary restraining order which would effectively delay the merger by another six months, according to the NY Post.

S&P 500

  • Colgate-Palmolive (CL) (Consumer Staples/Household Products) said that “there has been a little bit of softness in the US market”.
  • Discover Financial Services (DFS) (Financials/Consumer Finance) brands Redsys and Discover Global Network have signed an agreement enabling an extension of merchant acceptance throughout Spain.
  • Ford (F) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobile Manufacturers) - Argo AI President Rander said that the automaker is planning on will expanding testing of its third-generation self-driving Fusion Hybrid. The test vehicles will now be deployed in Detroit, as well as previous deployment in Pittsburgh, Palo Alto, Miami, Washington. 
  • Lockheed Martin (LMT) (Industrials/Aerospace & Defense) said that it was a year ahead of it goal of cutting the cost of the F-35 to USD 80mln per jet.
  • Marathon Oil (MRO) (Energy/Oil & Gas Refining & Marketing) was downgraded to neutral from overweight by Atlantic Equities, who cited the energy co.’s sensitivity to crude prices.
  • Morgan Stanley (MS) (Financials/Investment Banking & Brokerage) is looking to obtain a majority ownership of a joint venture in China. However, regulators there have not signed off on the notion.
  • Target (TGT) (Consumer Discretionary/General Merchandise Stores) announced in a blog post that its same-day delivery is now available through its website, with 65k products covered by the service.
  • Tyson Foods (TSN) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats) is to introduce its first plant-based and blended products alongside its new Raised & Rooted brand. Products will include plant-based nuggets and blended burgers (which are made with a combination of beef and plants), meanwhile, the food maker’s existing Aidells brand is to launch Aidells Whole Blends sausage and meatballs (which will be made with a combination of chicken and plant-based ingredients). Increasing competition in the space could effect plant based burger maker Beyond Meat (BYND) (Consumer Staples/Packaged Foods & Meats).

OTHER

  • Alibaba (BABA) (Consumer Discretionary/Internet & Direct Marketing Retail) is mulling raising up to USD 20bln before Q3, after it confidentially filed for a Hong Kong listing, newswires reported.
  • Nintendo (NTDOY) (Communication Services/ Entertainment) is to move some production of its Switch video game system away to Southeast Asia and away from China, as the co. looks to reduce its exposure to U.S. tariffs.
  • Renault (RNLSY, RNO FP) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles) chairman Senard defended his efforts to merge the company with Fiat Chrysler (FCAU) (Consumer Discretionary/Automobiles). He also criticized the French government for not supporting the merger.
  • Samsung (SSNLF) (Consumer Discretionary/Consumer Electronics) is reportedly looking into some kind of foldable phone, which, based on the illustrations in the filing, would aim to take advantage of flexible display technology.
  • Uber (UBER) (Industrials/Rail & Road), Lyft (LYFT) (Industrials/Rail & Road) - New York City is about to impose serious restrictions on app-based for-hire vehicles (such as like Lyft and Uber), reported the NY Daily times. “For too long, app companies have taken advantage of hardworking drivers, choking our streets with congestion and driving workers into poverty. That era will come to an end in New York City," Mayor de Blasio said on Wednesday.

UK Tory leadership Candidates Leadsom, McVey and Harper have been eliminated after the First Ballot
content:
• Boris Johnson received 114 votes
  • Jeremy Hunt received 43 votes
  • Michael Gove received 37
  • Dominic Raab received 27 votes
  • Sajid Javid received 23 votes
  • Matt Hancock received 20 votes
  • Rory Stewart received 19 votes
  • Andrea Leadsom received 11 votes
  • Mark Haper received 10 votes
  • Esther McVay received 9 votes
reaction_details: • Cable was flirting with the 1.27 handle prior to the announcement, on the results the pair slipped towards 1.2670; currently at 1.2676. This weakness in Sterling likely stemming from Boris Johnson receiving a much larger share than was expected at 114 votes, with Johnson seen as a candidate who is prepared to leave in a no-deal scenario. Most recently reports indicate that Johnson has assured senior Brexiteers, that he will leave the option of suspending parliament open.
analysis_details:
Next Steps:

- 16th June: UK TV Channel 4 will host a live debate between the candidates.

- 18th June: Second Vote on Tory Candidates. Candidates who receive under 33 votes are removed from the process. BBC will host a live election debate at this stage, scheduled for 20:00BST.

- 19th June: Third Vote on Tory Candidates. The candidate with the least number of votes is removed, no minimum threshold at this stage.

- 20th June: Fourth & Fifth Vote; the 1922 Committee have indicated that there are steps for further votes if required, though this is unlikely. After this stage only two leadership candidates will remain

- 22nd June: At this stage the approximate 160k Conservative members will begin voting for the next Tory leader, who will become PM.

- 22nd July: A new Tory leader will be announced at this point, replacing PM May as the standing PM.

RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 13th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • European equities are firmer [Euro Stoxx 50 +0.2%], deviating from their Asia-Pac counterparts
  • WTI & Brent are significantly firmer amidst reports that two oil tankers in the Gulf of Oman have been attacked
  • In FX, the USD remains relatively stead while safe havens are buoyed by ongoing geopolitical tensions
  • Looking ahead highlights include, US Import, Export Prices & Jobless Claims, New Zealand Manufacturing PMI. Supply from the US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded relatively flat/mixed following an uninspiring performance on Wall St where all major indices extended on losses as trade uncertainty lingered, with the downside led by energy and financials after a further decline in oil prices and yields. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.5%) were subdued but with losses in Australia stemmed as mixed jobs data supported the case for further rate cuts by the RBA, while the Japanese benchmark was pressured as energy names suffered the brunt from the recent 4% drop in crude and with the nation’s largest megabank MUFG weighed as it faces its first ever Q1 loss due to a JPY 300bln impairment related to its Indonesia JV. Hang Seng (U/C) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were initially weaker after the recent miss on lending data, as well as ongoing trade uncertainty with President Trump continuing to send mixed signals regarding a trade deal and as the Chinese government mouthpiece Global Times suggested Beijing is preparing for ties worsening. Hong Kong underperformed again amid disruptions following the mass protests and as the Legislative Council was set to hold a meeting regarding the extradition bill today, although this was later postponed, and stocks gradually rebounded from lows. US equity futures were also active and deteriorated overnight amid the widespread risk averse tone and technical selling in which DJIA futures slipped below the 26k level and E-mini Nasdaq 100 pulled back from resistance at 7.5k. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially higher as the weakness across stocks spurred a flight to quality and amid the declining global yield environment, although the gains in bonds were aggressively pared after an abysmal 30yr auction in which the b/c printed its lowest since November 2017 and the tail in price spiked to 0.87 from 0.03. 

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 28-day reverse repo for a daily net injection of CNY 90bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8934 (Prev. 6.8932)

China Vice Premier Liu He said there is room to expand financial support for quality GDP growth and that domestic economy remains stable and healthy, while he added that China continues to push ahead with economic rebalancing. Furthermore, Liu He commented that the domestic economy is facing external pressure but suggested long-term trends are good. (Newswires)

China CBIRC Vice Chairman said China will prevent flooding of the financial system with liquidity, while he added that a certain country is trying to curb China's growth. (Newswires)

Global Times tweeted that the conduct of the US has laid bare that the US itself is a non-market economy and that its actions have nothing to do with the laws and principles of the market. (Twitter)

Economists expect the PBoC to either lower interest rates or RRR in the upcoming weeks, while they think that moderate China inflation and global dovish environment may provide more space for officials to adjust money and credit supply to counter risks if trade tensions escalate. (China Daily)

HKMA said HKD, FX and money markets are operating in an orderly manner, while it added that domestic banks are well capitalized and highly liquid. (Newswires)

US

US House Oversight Committee voted to hold AG Barr and Commerce Secretary Ross in contempt of Congress regarding dispute on documents related to 2020 census, while there were separate reports that Former White House Communications Director Hick agreed to provide a closed-door testimony to the House committee. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK PM candidate Johnson has privately assured senior Brexiteers that he will leave open the option of suspending parliament to force through a no-deal exit from the EU, according to sources. (Times)

Italy’s government won a confidence motion in the lower house which paves the way for the approval of reforms on public tender rules aimed at supporting its economy. Subsequently, Eurogroup Head Centeno expects Italy to achieve its targets in regard to debt. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITICAL

Several Saudi-led coaltition air strikes have been reported on Sanaa, the capital of Yemen., according to Al-Masirah TV; no confirmation as of yet from the coalition on this. (Newswires)

US State Department said it is ready to continue working level denuclearization talks with North Korea. (Yonhap)

Russian Lawmaker states that the plans by the US to deploy spy drones in Poland is of concern to Moscow, stating that Poland could be targeted in a retaliatory strike in the scenario of an attack on Russia., IFX. (Interfax)

Turkish Foreign Minister states that it is not possible to confirm that a full ceasefire in Idlib has been achieved. (Newswires)

Iranian supreme leader told Japanese PM Abe that Iran will not negotiate with the US. (Newswires)

 

EQUITIES

European equities are higher across the board [Eurostoxx 50 +0.4%] as the region deviated from the subdued Asia-Pac lead. Sectors are all in the green with the energy sector outperforming (+0.6%) amid the surge in energy prices as two oil tankers were reportedly attacked near the key shipping channel, the Strait of Hormuz (see the Commodities section for a full briefing). Meanwhile, some defensive sectors are lagging its peers with the likes of Utilities (+0.1%) and Consumer Staples (Unch) little changed. Elsewhere, Germany’s 5G auction ended in which raised EUR 6.55bln, above estimates of EUR 3-5bln. Four companies won bids: Deutsche Telekom (+0.7%) won 130MHz, Vodafone (+1.1%) won 130MHz, Telefonica Deutschland (3.5%) won 90MHz and 1&1 Drillisch (+7.5%) won 70MHz. In terms of individual movers, Thales (+2.3%) shares are supported after the Co. raised its EBIT outlook. Wirecard (+3.2%) rose to the top of the DAX amid a positive broker move. On the flip side, ProsiebenSat1 (-3.9%) fell to the foot of the Stoxx 600 amid ex-dividend trade.

FX

CHF/AUD - Flanking the G10 ranks after the SNB refrained from raising its assessment of the Franc from highly valued despite acknowledging that the currency has appreciated since the last quarterly policy review in March and repeating the need to maintain NIRP and intervention. Board members also noted elevated risks of heightened demand for the Chf, more pronounced downside risks to the Swiss economy due to external and reiterated that there is room to loosen the monetary reins further, but signalled steady rates through the 3 year forecast horizon. Note, the 3 month Libor target and range was replaced with a new benchmark rate, but for purely technical reasons and the impending switch from Libor to SARON. Usd/Chf and Eur/Chf are both lower in wake of the policy pronouncements, statement and revised forecasts for growth and inflation, with the former retreating towards 0.9900 again and latter eyeing 1.1200. Conversely, the Aussie has been undermined by mixed labour data that underpins prospects for another RBA rate cut, with Aud/Usd hovering just above 0.6900 and Aud/Nzd only a few pips away from 1.0500. For the record, headline payrolls beat consensus, but mainly due to temp jobs and the unemployment rate remained unchanged against forecast for a dip, while decent option expiries at 0.6930 look fairly safe at this stage.

CAD/JPY - The Loonie and Yen are both firmer vs the Greenback amidst an escalation in US-China trade angst and geopolitical concerns, with Usd/Cad easing back between 1.3343-14 parameters and Usd/Jpy holding in a 108.53-17 range. A relatively sharp rebound in crude prices on reports of tanker attacks in the Gulf of Oman has underpinned the Loonie, while the Yen is benefiting from a degree of safe-haven positioning, like the Franc and Gold, but also wary of balanced expiry interest given 1.5 bn running off from 107.90-108.10 and 1.6 bn between 108.65-80.

EUR/NZD/GBP - Narrowly mixed vs the Buck as the DXY nestles near 97.000 after the post-US CPI bounce, but is capped ahead of resistance just above the round number in the form of 100 and 10 DMAs (97.020 and 97.033 respectively). The single currency is pivoting 1.1300 having failed to close above Fib resistance at 1.1338 on Wednesday, with support coming in around 1.1280 and option expiries nearby at 1.1310-30 (1.1bn) then 1.1345-60 (1.2 bn). Elsewhere, the Kiwi is seeing some bearish contagion from its Antipodean counterpart, but holding up better vs the Usd within a 0.6587-65 band ahead of NZ manufacturing PMI. Meanwhile, the Pound has lost grip of 1.2700 vs the Usd and Eur/Gbp is back over 0.8900 on no deal Brexit risk in the run up to the start of the Tory leadership race and first elimination vote.

EM - The Lira has given up more post-CBRT gains and is now somewhat weaker than it was prior to the policy meet on latest remarks from Turkey reaffirming intentions to go ahead with the Russian S-400 order, and as the Defence Minister claims that Syrian Government forces attacked a Turkish observation post in Idlib. Usd/Try has rebounded towards 5.8500.

Australian Employment Change (May) 42.3k vs. Exp. 17.5k (Prev. 28.4k). (Newswires) Australian Unemployment Rate (May) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 5.2%) Australian Participation Rate (May) 66.0% vs. Exp. 65.8% (Prev. 65.8%)

Notable FX Expiries:

- EUR/USD: 1.1235-50 (2.5BLN), 1.1310-30 (1.1BLN), 1.1345-60 (1.2BLN)

- AUD/USD: 0.6935 (1BLN), 0.6950 (709M)

- USD/JPY: 107.90-108.10 (1.5BLN), 108.65-80 (1.6BLN)

Swiss government sees growth for 2019 at 1.2% (Prev. 1.1%), 2020 1.7% (Prev. 1.7%); CPI in 2019 at 0.6% (Prev. 0.4%), 2020 0.6% (0.6%). (Newswires)

SNB 3M Target LIBOR Rate -0.75% vs. Exp. -0.75% (Prev. -0.75%)

- SNB repeated language around FX; he situation in FX market is still fragile, maintaining that expansionary monetary policy and intervention are essential

- Retained highly valued assessment of CHF and noted that the Franc is stronger than in March (prior meeting)

- Introduced a new policy rate to replace the 3-month Libor target, as the future of Libor is not guaranteed; will keep the rate as close to -0.75% as is possible.

- Risks to the baseline scenario are still to the downside and more pronounced than in March, updated inflation forecasts assumes unchanged rates throughout the forecast horizon

SNB President Jordan says the SNB still has room for expansionary policy, adding that the central bank decide on intervension when necessary and will not discuss specific levels. (Newswires)

FIXED INCOME

10 year benchmarks extended recovery gains to 171.65, 130.43 and 127-09 respectively as supportive macro/fundamental impulses were supplemented by safe-haven buying amidst a raft of worrying geopolitical headlines. However, Bunds, Gilts and US Treasuries have all subsequently drifted back down from best levels, and technical factors may have prompted the loss of momentum or bout of consolidation, as the former pulled up just shy of chart resistance at 171.66 and its UK equivalent faded a whisker before this week’s peak (130.45 set on Monday). Meanwhile, USTs have more issuance to digest after a more mixed set of 10 year auction results compared to the relatively strong 3 year sale with the last leg comprising Usd16 bn long bonds, and data in the form of import/export prices alongside weekly claims.

COMMODITIES

WTI and Brent futures surged higher in early European trade and have held onto most of their gains amid a number of bullish headlines for the oil complex: 1) a UAE Port Official stated that an oil tanker is currently on fire in the Gulf of Oman, with subsequent reports indicating that two oil tankers (of which one belongs to a Japanese shipping company, and is carrying chemical materials) have been attacked by torpedoes, although no one has yet claimed the attacks. Analyst point out that the magnitude of the spike in energy prices could be attributed more to the location of the attack, i.e. close to the Strait of Hormuz (a key shipping channel), for reference, four oil tankers have been damaged in the same area in the last month. Fingers have been pointed at Iran for last months attacks, although Tehran has denied any involvement. 2) On the OPEC front, reports stated that Kazakhstan has reduced its oil output to 1.76mln BPD for the January to May period, which exceeds their obligations under the current OPEC+ pact. The oil producer has also indicated support for an extension to the OPEC+ deal, whilst Algeria has also floated the idea of an OPEC+ supply cut of 1.8mln BPD (currently 1.2mln BPD) in H2. 3) Russian President Putin stating that relations with the US are worsening, which comes in the context of US President Trump stating overnight that he is considering sanctions to block the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, and indicating that Germany is at risk by depending on energy from Russia. Brent futures currently reside around the USD 61.75/bbl mark, having opened trade sub-60/bbl and hit a high of around USD 62.60/bbl thus far. Looking ahead, the OPEC Monthly Report will be released at 11:40BST/0540EDT with focus on any revision to global oil demand following EIA Short Term Energy Outlook downgrading its forecast. Elsewhere, gold prices (+0.3%) hold onto the majority of recent gains, as the yellow metal moves more to the risk environment as opposed to the Greenback amid the heightening geopolitical tensions as mentioned above. Copper prices have failed to rebound amid global growth pressures and as trade tensions outweigh supply woes. Finally, Dalian iron ore resumed its rally, buoyed by expectations of tight supply and high demand.

UAE Port Official states that an oil tanker is currently on fire in the Gulf of Oman; subsequent reports indicate that 2 oil tankers have been attacked in the region. Following this it was reported that the Frontline tanker was struck by a torpedo. And the damaged tanker, Front Altair has sunk according to IRNA (though, this was subsequently denied by a Frontline spokesman). For reference, Japanese shipping Co. Kokua Sangyo confirm that one of their ships carrying chemical materials was attacked in the Gulf. (Newswires)

Kazakhstan has reduced oil output to 1.76mln BPD in the period of Jan-May, exceeding its obligations, the country also supports the extension of the OPEC+ output pact until year-end. (Newswires)

subject: OPEC monthly report: OPEC crude production fell 236k bpd in May to 29.88mln bpd, according to secondary sources
content:
• Crude oil output decreased mostly in Iran, I.R., Nigeria, Saudi Arabia and Venezuela, while production increased in Iraq, Angola and Gabon
  • For 2019, oil demand growth is forecast at around 1.14mln bpd; 70kbpd less than the prior report. The downward revision was mainly to account for sluggish oil demand data in the OECD region during Q1 2019.
  • In 2019, demand for OPEC crude is forecast at 30.5mln bpd, around 1.1mln bpd lower than the estimated 2018 level.
  • Non-OPEC oil supply growth is forecast to average 2.14mln BPD; unchanged from the prior report despite some downward revisions for the US, due to lower-than-expected output in Q1 2019, and for Norway and Brazil due to lower-than-expected production in Q3 2019 and Q4 2019.

subject: ANALYSIS: Conservative Leader Candidates, Brexit Views & Next Steps
content:
10 Candidates have been confirmed for the initial vote on Thursday, 13th June. Candidates are listed below in order of the number of Tory MP’s who have publicly declared their support for them; hence, this order can be used as an approximation for the Tory parties ranking on the candidates.

  • Boris Johnson (76) – The clear frontrunner and bookies favourite to win at this stage. Johnson’s line on Brexit is that he wants the UK to leave the EU on October 31st with or without a deal; and that he wants the Irish Backstop removed from the WA. Most recently, Johnson has ruled out making the GBP 39bln divorce payment to the EU unless improved WA terms are presented.
  • Jeremy Hunt (31) – Seeking to renegotiate the WA, as he believes there is a chance to renegotiate, particularly over the Irish Backstop. Remains prepared for a no-deal Brexit scenario, but firmly believes that changes to the WA can be negotiated and agreed by the 31st October.
  • Michael Gove (30) – Willing to accept a delay, if the EU is prepared to grant one (recent commentary indicates that the EU would be willing to allow a extension if there is seen to be a reasonable chance of an agreement resulting from it) instead of a no-deal scenario; though has previously stated that he wants to leave by October 31st and as such would accept a no-deal Brexit. As such, is prepared to return to Brussels in order to negotiate changes to the backstop.
  • Dominic Raab (21) – Prepared to accept a no-deal Brexit, but seeks to renegotiate a fairer Brexit deal with the EU; to make a offer to replace the Irish Backstop utilising the Malthouse compromise; and leaving on WTO terms is significantly better than leaving with a ‘flawed deal’.
  • Sajid Javid (18) – Believes that a technical solution to the Irish Backstop could vastly improve the WA. However, on this point the EU have stated that while they are open to utilising technical solutions, though this is not a viable option any time soon. Believes preparations need to be made for a no-deal Brexit, but does not seek a hard Brexit.
  • Matt Hancock (15) – Takes the view that a no-deal Brexit is not a viable scenario, as it would be blocked in Parliament; therefore, his accepted scenarios are not leaving or leaving with a deal. Additionally, wants a time-limit to the Irish Backstop with a view to use technology to aid the border issue further down the line.
  • Mark Harper (6) – Wants the UK to achieve a deal, though accepts that leaving without one is still a possibility/option; would look to renegotiate terms around the Irish Backstop.
  • Rory Stewart (6) – Strongly against a no-deal Brexit, viewed as not being a viable option. Believes the focus should be on securing a parliamentary majority for the WA, as he does not believe the EU will offer a alternative deal. Supports the idea of a citizens assembly in order to achieve a compromise on the WA.
  • Esther Mcvey (5) – Strongly supports a no-deal, believes the UK should leave on WTO terms. Would attempt to achieve this by preventing any additional votes on the UK’s exit from the EU prior to the October 31st extension deadline.
  • Andrea Leadsom (4) – The UK’s departure from the EU by October 31st is a ‘hard red line’, which is to occur in all circumstances; after agreeing a exit strategy with the EU in order to protect workers rights. Would look to increasing exit preparations, particularly those concerning alternatives to the Irish Backstop.

 

Next steps in the Tory Leadership Process:

- 13th June: First vote on Tory candidates. To advance to the next round a MP must receive at least 16 votes. However, in the scenario they all receive the threshold number of votes then the MP with the least votes is removed.

- 16th June: UK TV Channel 4 will host a live debate between the candidates.

- 18th June: Second Vote on Tory Candidates. Candidates who receive under 33 votes are removed from the process. BBC will host a live election debate at this stage, scheduled for 20:00BST.

- 19th June: Third Vote on Tory Candidates. The candidate with the least number of votes is removed, no minimum threshold at this stage.

- 20th June: Fourth & Fifth Vote; the 1922 Committee have indicated that there are steps for further votes if required, though this is unlikely. After this stage only two leadership candidates will remain

- 22nd June: At this stage the approximate 160k Conservative members will begin voting for the next Tory leader, who will become PM.

- 22nd July: A new Tory leader will be announced at this point, replacing PM May as the standing PM.

subject: Swiss 3M Target LIBOR Rate -0.75% vs. Exp. -0.75% (Prev. -0.75%)
content:
• Repeats that the situation in FX market is still fragile, maintaining that expansionary monetary policy and intervention are essential
  • Also retains highly valued assessment of the CHF, and note that the Franc is stronger than it was in March
  • Introduces new policy reference rate to replace the 3-month Libor target, and will use this to communicate monetary policy decisions; will keep the new rate as close to -0.75% as is possible
  • Inflationary pressures are likely to remain moderate, risks to the baseline scenario are still to the downside and more pronounced than in March
  • Updated inflation forecasts assume unchanged rates through the entire forecast horizon

SNAP ANALYSIS: Oil Prices Spike
content:
• A number of bullish headlines for the oil complex have crossed markets in the last hour. Firstly, a UAE Port Official stated that an oil tanker is currently on fire in the Gulf of Oman, with subsequent reports indicating that 2 oil tankers have been attacked. Secondly, Kazakhstan has reduced its oil output to 1.76mln BPD for the January to May period, which exceeds their obligations under the current OPEC+ pact; country have also indicated their support for an extension to the OPEC+ deal, whilst Algeria was also floating the idea of an OPEC+ supply cut of 1.8mln BPD (currently 1.2mln BPD) in H2. Thirdly, Russian President Putin stating that relations with the US are worsening, which comes in the context of US President Trump stating overnight that he is considering sanctions to block the Nord Stream 2 pipeline, and indicating that Germany is at risk by depending on energy from Russia. 
  • These headlines have seen a spike in both WTI and Brent since 07:00BST; with WTI futures moving from around USD 51.50 to USD 52.59 currently, with a high print of USD 53.11 and Brent futures moving higher from USD 60.70 to USD 61.83 with a high print of USD 62.64. The bullish headlines have significantly eroded the recent downside seen in the complex on both the API and EIA reporting unexpected builds this week; and its worth bearing in mind that we are expecting the OPEC Monthly Oil Report Today, which may provide further upward pressure on prices if they take the same line as the EIA did in their monthly report in downgrading oil demand for both 2019 & 2020.

subject: Bunds: building a firmer base and platform to retest recent highs?
content: The core Eurozone bond has rebounded a bit further from this week’s lows following a marginal initial markdown from Wednesday’s 171.48 close to trade up at 171.58 vs 171.45 on the Eurex open. This is in line with a renewed bid along the US Treasury complex on heightened global trade and diplomatic tensions alongside a general dovish shift in CB policy and/or guidance. Ahead, Eurozone ip and Italian supply in the form of multi-tranche conventional auctions after a well received 20 year syndication and pending more deliberations on Rome’s budget from the Eurogroup.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

13th June 2019

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded mostly downbeat following an uninspiring performance on Wall St where all major indices extended on losses as trade uncertainty lingered, with the downside led by energy and financials after a further decline in oil prices and yields. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were subdued but with losses in Australia stemmed as mixed jobs data supported the case for further rate cuts by the RBA, while the Japanese benchmark was pressured as energy names suffered the brunt from the recent 4% drop in crude and with the nation’s largest megabank MUFG weighed as it faces its first ever Q1 loss due to a JPY 300bln impairment related to its Indonesia JV. Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were also weaker after the recent miss on lending data, as well as ongoing trade uncertainty with President Trump continuing to send mixed signals regarding a trade deal and as the Chinese government mouthpiece Global Times suggested Beijing is preparing for ties worsening. Hong Kong underperformed again amid disruptions following the mass protests and as the Legislative Council was set to hold a meeting regarding the extradition bill today, although this was later postponed and stocks gradually rebounded from lows. US equity futures were also active and deteriorated overnight amid the widespread risk averse tone and technical selling in which DJIA futures slipped below the 26k level and Emini Nasdaq 100 pulled back from resistance at 7.5k.

FTSE 100

Ex-Divs - 3i Group (III LN), NMC Health (NMC LN), Persimmon (PSN LN), Severn Trent (SVT LN), and WPP Plc (WPP LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out, trimming 4.54 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

Housing names – RICS survey showed that the UK housing market steadied in May amid the delay to the UK’s departure from the EU [-10 vs. Exp. -21.0 (Prev. -23.0, Rev. -22)]. Elsewhere, the UK housing secretary has called on the CMA to widen its investigation into the mis-selling of leasehold homes. Reports suggest around 100,000 new-build homes have been sold on leases that were subject to substantial increases in ground rents and the charging of “permission fees” for home improvement. (Newswires/Times)

Oil names - WTI crude futures traded flat to provide much-needed respite after the prior day’s 4% drop to briefly below the USD 51.00/bbl level, with the losses due to this week’s bearish inventory data in which both API and EIA reports showed surprise builds in headline crude stockpiles.

Mining Names with Exposure to South Africa - The AMCU are to meet the South African platinum producers on Friday 14th June and demand an increase in wages for its workers after higher palladium prices and a softer ZAR has boosted profits for producers. (Newswires)

RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 13th June 2019
content:
To download the report, please click here If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can now do so under the Research Suite section of the portal. To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category. 

  • Asia-Pac stocks remain lower as the risk-off sentiment spills over from the US; amidst negative Chinese rhetoric on a US trade deal
  • US President Trump remains optimistic on achieving a deal with China, but added that tariffs on the rest of Chinese imports will be imposed if no deal can be achieved; has no deadline for these tariffs
  • USD remains firm to the detriment of G10 counterparts, with Cable pressured after the Labour party’s parliament control bill was defeated
  • Looking ahead highlights include, German CPI, EZ Industrial Production, US Import, Export Prices & Jobless Claims, New Zealand Manufacturing PMI, SNB Rate Decision. Supply from Italy & US

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian equity markets traded mostly downbeat following an uninspiring performance on Wall St where all major indices extended on losses as trade uncertainty lingered, with the downside led by energy and financials after a further decline in oil prices and yields. ASX 200 (Unch.) and Nikkei 225 (-0.7%) were subdued but with losses in Australia stemmed as mixed jobs data supported the case for further rate cuts by the RBA, while the Japanese benchmark was pressured as energy names suffered the brunt from the recent 4% drop in crude and with the nation’s largest megabank MUFG weighed as it faces its first ever Q1 loss due to a JPY 300bln impairment related to its Indonesia JV. Hang Seng (-0.8%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were also weaker after the recent miss on lending data, as well as ongoing trade uncertainty with President Trump continuing to send mixed signals regarding a trade deal and as the Chinese government mouthpiece Global Times suggested Beijing is preparing for ties worsening. Hong Kong underperformed again amid disruptions following the mass protests and as the Legislative Council was set to hold a meeting regarding the extradition bill today, although this was later postponed, and stocks gradually rebounded from lows. US equity futures were also active and deteriorated overnight amid the widespread risk averse tone and technical selling in which DJIA futures slipped below the 26k level and E-mini Nasdaq 100 pulled back from resistance at 7.5k. Finally, 10yr JGBs were initially higher as the weakness across stocks spurred a flight to quality and amid the declining global yield environment, although the gains in bonds were aggressively pared after an abysmal 30yr auction in which the b/c printed its lowest since November 2017 and the tail in price spiked to 0.87 from 0.03. 

PBoC injected CNY 100bln via 28-day reverse repo for a daily net injection of CNY 90bln. (Newswires) PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.8934 (Prev. 6.8932)

US President Trump said he has a feeling the US is going to make a deal with China but added that he will impose tariffs on the rest of imports from China if a deal cannot be made, while he later commented that he has no deadline for implementing the next round of tariffs on China. (Newswires)

China Vice Premier Liu He said there is room to expand financial support for quality GDP growth and that domestic economy remains stable and healthy, while he added that China continues to push ahead with economic rebalancing. Furthermore, Liu He commented that the domestic economy is facing external pressure but suggested long-term trends are good. (Newswires)

China CBIRC Vice Chairman said China will prevent flooding of the financial system with liquidity, while he added that a certain country is trying to curb China's growth. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said China's state media will publish more heavyweight commentaries criticizing the US and demonstrating China's determination which suggests that Beijing is preparing for ties worsening. Furthermore, Global Times later tweeted that the conduct of the US has laid bare that the US itself is a non-market economy and that its actions have nothing to do with the laws and principles of the market. (Twitter)

Economists expect the PBoC to either lower interest rates or RRR in the upcoming weeks, while they think that moderate China inflation and global dovish environment may provide more space for officials to adjust money and credit supply to counter risks if trade tensions escalate. (China Daily)

HKMA said HKD, FX and money markets are operating in an orderly manner, while it added that domestic banks are well capitalized and highly liquid. (Newswires)

UK/EU

UK opposition Labour party Brexit vote to seize control over parliamentary business as an attempt to block a no-deal was defeated by 309 vs 298 votes, while there were comments from Labour Brexit Chief Starmer that the vote was just the start of efforts to stop a no-deal and that they stand ready to do whatever mechanism available. (Newswires)

UK PM candidate Johnson has privately assured senior Brexiteers that he will leave open the option of suspending parliament to force through a no-deal exit from the EU, according to sources. (Times)

Italy’s government won a confidence motion in the lower house which paves the way for the approval of reforms on public tender rules aimed at supporting its economy. (Newswires)

UK RICS Housing Survey (May) -10 vs. Exp. -21.0 (Prev. -23.0, Rev. -22). (Newswires)

FX

In FX markets, the DXY slightly eased below the 97.00 level but still held on to most the prior day’s gains as its major counterparts struggled to nurse recent losses with EUR/USD and GBP/USD below the 1.1300 and 1.2700 handles respectively, with the latter pressured after UK opposition Labour party’s attempts to seize control over parliamentary business and block a no-deal Brexit was defeated by 309 vs 298 votes. Elsewhere, the risk averse tone spurred demand for safe haven JPY and weighed on high-beta currencies with AUD/USD also dragged by mixed jobs data in which headline Employment Change topped estimates but the Unemployment Rate remained at 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 5.2%), which suggests the RBA remain on track for a further cut this year and saw the Aussie 3yr yield drop to a record low under 1.00%.

Australian Employment Change (May) 42.3k vs. Exp. 17.5k (Prev. 28.4k). (Newswires) Australian Unemployment Rate (May) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.1% (Prev. 5.2%) Australian Participation Rate (May) 66.0% vs. Exp. 65.8% (Prev. 65.8%)

COMMODITIES

Commodities were mixed as WTI crude futures traded flat to provide much-needed respite after the prior day’s 4% drop to briefly below the USD 51.00/bbl level, with the losses due to this week’s bearish inventory data in which both API and EIA reports showed surprise builds in headline crude stockpiles. Elsewhere, gold prices were relatively unchanged as safe-haven demand for the precious metal was counterbalanced by a resolute greenback, while copper was dampened by the mostly risk adverse tone across the region.

Algeria is mulling the idea of an OPEC+ supply cut of 1.8mln BPD (up from 1.2mln BPD) in H2 and still expects the 1.2mln BPD cut to roll over beyond June, according to OPEC sources. (Newswires)

GEOPOLITCAL

US President Trump said the US and Poland are mulling sending 2,000 troops from Germany to Poland and that he is discussing a big transaction with Poland. Furthermore, US President Trump is considering sanctions to block Nord Stream 2 and suggested that Germany is putting itself at risk by depending on Russian energy. (Newswires)

Iranian President Rouhani said the meeting with Japanese PM Abe was successful and that Tehran welcomes improving Japanese ties. Rouhani also commented that Iran will remain committed to the 2015 nuclear deal and that it is important for regional security, while he added that Japan and Iran oppose nuclear weapons. (Newswires) US State Department said it is ready to continue working level denuclearization talks with North Korea. (Yonhap)

US

The curve bull-steepened after a slightly soft CPI report resulted in further bets of looser Fed policy. Trump optimism (though a repeat of his comments from this week) saw slight selling. The Treasury sold 10s, which tailed 0.1bps, and sold at the lowest yield since 2016. The internals were also encouraging, and there has been no sign of a collapse in the foreign bid so far at the Treasury auctions, with indirects taking 65.6% (six auction average 61.8%), and up from the 53.3% at the May auction. Cover was also decent at 2.49, above recent averages. At settlement, the 2s30s part of the curve was almost 5bps steeper. On Thursday, the Treasury will sell USD 16bln of 30s; recent auctions in the 30-year sector have tailed. However, TD Securities suggests that curve steepening might provide demand for long-end debt. Recent averages imply a tail of around 0.4bps, with a 74% buy side takedown (14% directs, 60% indirects). T-note futures (M9) settled 6+ ticks higher at 126-20+.

US House Oversight Committee voted to hold AG Barr and Commerce Secretary Ross in contempt of Congress regarding dispute on documents related to 2020 census, while there were separate reports that Former White House Communications Director Hick agreed to provide a closed-door testimony to the House committee. (Newswires)

PRE-MARKET CHINESE STOCK NEWS: Chinese New Yuan Loans and Aggregate Financing slightly missed estimates
content:
Huawei - White House said it will now meet 2-year deadline for Huawei ban for contractors in defense law. (Newswires)

Insurers - China is said to be looking to establish an insurance connect. (Newswires)

Protests - Hong Kong government is to temporary close its HQ on Thursday and Friday amid protests, while it was also reported that the Hong Kong Legislative Council is to hold extradition bill meeting today at 1100HKT. (Newswires) 

 

Trade

US President Trump said he has a feeling the US is going to make a deal with China but added that he will impose tariffs on the rest of imports from China if a deal cannot be made, while he later commented that he has no deadline for implementing the next round of tariffs on China. (Newswires)

China Global Times Editor said China's state media will publish more heavyweight commentaries criticizing the US and demonstrating China's determination which suggests that Beijing is preparing for ties worsening. (Twitter) 

 

Other News

Economists expect the PBoC to either lower interest rates or RRR in the upcoming weeks, while they think that moderate China inflation and global dovish environment may provide more space for officials to adjust money and credit supply to counter risks if trade tensions escalate. (China Daily)

HKMA said HKD, FX and money markets are operating in an orderly manner, while it added that domestic banks are well capitalized and highly liquid. (Newswires)

 

Data Recap

  • Chinese New Yuan Loans (CNY)(May) 1180B vs. Exp. 1225.0B (Prev. 1020.0B). (Newswires) 
  • Chinese Aggregate Financing (May) 1400B vs. Exp. 1450B (Prev. 1360B) 
  • Chinese Money Supply M2 (May) Y/Y 8.5% vs. Exp. 8.6% (Prev. 8.5%)
